nodes.html:
<button class="carousel-item__media-content-container" type="button" aria-haspopup="true" @click="openModal("article", null, "Pursuing a rewarding Career in the Digital economy- Workshop Overview!", "Dorothy Nakaggwa", "https://res.cloudinary.com/baobab-staging/image/upload/v1679593436/Pursuing-a-rewarding-career_-_Article_Media_Card_Header_qhdiqh_orkzmb_nmcnj3", "Pursuing a rewarding Career in the Digital economy- Workshop Overview!

    Last week I had a wonderful time hosting a live zoom workshop on “Pursuing a Rewarding Career in the Digital Economy.” It’s conversations like these that remind me of the power we have as young people to change the narrative of youth unemployment that has for so long ravaged the African Continent.

    As a freelance writer who has leveraged the internet to build a career online, it was a privilege to talk to other young people on how we can embrace digital technologies and position ourselves for the new opportunities created by the internet.

    In today’s blog, I’ll go over a few things that we talked about, and I hope you’ll learn about the potential of the internet to challenge unemployment in Africa.

    African Countries have had a tough time creating formal sector jobs for the youth for decades. As more youth enter the workforce, and thousands of graduates walk out of universities each year, many face the challenge of finding meaningful work on the continent.

    For graduates, this can be frustrating since most of us spend on average four years preparing to serve in different sectors of the economy. In the end, we are hit with the reality that these sectors can’t provide enough jobs for all of us.

    The Good News…

    Despite the grim employment outlook, there is a silver lining for young people ready to jump at the opportunities created by digital technologies. Whether you’re a tech-savvy or not, I believe we could all benefit from this revolution in different ways.

    A recent World Bank report on the future of work in Africa suggested that “If widely adopted, digital technologies hold the promise of helping firms grow, create more jobs for everyone, and most importantly increase the employment rate not only for university graduates, but for those workers who have a secondary, or even a primary level of education.”

    We can all agree that digital technologies are changing the nature of work and structure of employment, globally. The internet has created new markets, new roles, and new types of employment that initially didn’t exist.

    But how can young Africans embrace this revolution?

    First off, we talked about the forms of digital exclusion among young people in Africa. These included:

    Unware: These young people have experience with using the internet but don’t know where to find opportunities online.

    Unready: These have little or no internet experience and the key barriers are little or no internet access and minimal IT skills.

    Uninterested: This group has no internet experience and not interested in learning about opportunities online.

    Unable: This group has Poor literacy and English Language skills and can’t understand the value of the internet.

    Most of the workshop attendees were Unaware, and a few were Unready. This shows that we need to educate ourselves on the opportunities created by digital technologies and build our skill sets so we can position ourselves for this revolution.

    The “hidden” online job Market

    I call it “hidden” because no one in school ever mentioned to us the possibility of building a career online —  with just your laptop and an internet connection. The online job market offers individuals with in-demand skills an opportunity to build a rewarding career irrespective of your gender, nationality, and geographical location.

    During the workshop, we explored some in-demand skills and the new opportunities created by the internet. The skills included Virtual assistant, Accounting and bookkeeping, Google analytics, Digital Marketing, eCommerce, web design and development, etc. The jobs created by the internet included SEO specialist, Digital Marketer, online tutor, content marketer, User experience designer, etc.

    Workspaces Vs. Workplaces

    We couldn’t end the discussion without talking about the rise of remote working. As more businesses transition to new business models, remote working is becoming the new normal. This offers young Africans endless opportunities to serve in the virtual world of work and collaborate with business outside their geographical location.

    In conclusion

    Digital technologies have the potential to create more and better jobs for young Africans. It’s time for us to look at how we can build global in-demand skills and create added value to work in the digital economy.

    What are your thoughts on digital technologies and the future of work in Africa? Share with us in the comment section.");

nodes.html:
<button class="carousel-item__media-content-container" type="button" aria-haspopup="true" @click="openModal("article", null, "Pursuing a rewarding Career in the Digital economy- Workshop Overview!", "Dorothy Nakaggwa", "https://res.cloudinary.com/baobab-staging/image/upload/v1679593436/Pursuing-a-rewarding-career_-_Article_Media_Card_Header_qhdiqh_orkzmb_nmcnj3", "Pursuing a rewarding Career in the Digital economy- Workshop Overview!

    Last week I had a wonderful time hosting a live zoom workshop on “Pursuing a Rewarding Career in the Digital Economy.” It’s conversations like these that remind me of the power we have as young people to change the narrative of youth unemployment that has for so long ravaged the African Continent.

    As a freelance writer who has leveraged the internet to build a career online, it was a privilege to talk to other young people on how we can embrace digital technologies and position ourselves for the new opportunities created by the internet.

    In today’s blog, I’ll go over a few things that we talked about, and I hope you’ll learn about the potential of the internet to challenge unemployment in Africa.

    African Countries have had a tough time creating formal sector jobs for the youth for decades. As more youth enter the workforce, and thousands of graduates walk out of universities each year, many face the challenge of finding meaningful work on the continent.

    For graduates, this can be frustrating since most of us spend on average four years preparing to serve in different sectors of the economy. In the end, we are hit with the reality that these sectors can’t provide enough jobs for all of us.

    The Good News…

    Despite the grim employment outlook, there is a silver lining for young people ready to jump at the opportunities created by digital technologies. Whether you’re a tech-savvy or not, I believe we could all benefit from this revolution in different ways.

    A recent World Bank report on the future of work in Africa suggested that “If widely adopted, digital technologies hold the promise of helping firms grow, create more jobs for everyone, and most importantly increase the employment rate not only for university graduates, but for those workers who have a secondary, or even a primary level of education.”

    We can all agree that digital technologies are changing the nature of work and structure of employment, globally. The internet has created new markets, new roles, and new types of employment that initially didn’t exist.

    But how can young Africans embrace this revolution?

    First off, we talked about the forms of digital exclusion among young people in Africa. These included:

    Unware: These young people have experience with using the internet but don’t know where to find opportunities online.

    Unready: These have little or no internet experience and the key barriers are little or no internet access and minimal IT skills.

    Uninterested: This group has no internet experience and not interested in learning about opportunities online.

    Unable: This group has Poor literacy and English Language skills and can’t understand the value of the internet.

    Most of the workshop attendees were Unaware, and a few were Unready. This shows that we need to educate ourselves on the opportunities created by digital technologies and build our skill sets so we can position ourselves for this revolution.

    The “hidden” online job Market

    I call it “hidden” because no one in school ever mentioned to us the possibility of building a career online —  with just your laptop and an internet connection. The online job market offers individuals with in-demand skills an opportunity to build a rewarding career irrespective of your gender, nationality, and geographical location.

    During the workshop, we explored some in-demand skills and the new opportunities created by the internet. The skills included Virtual assistant, Accounting and bookkeeping, Google analytics, Digital Marketing, eCommerce, web design and development, etc. The jobs created by the internet included SEO specialist, Digital Marketer, online tutor, content marketer, User experience designer, etc.

    Workspaces Vs. Workplaces

    We couldn’t end the discussion without talking about the rise of remote working. As more businesses transition to new business models, remote working is becoming the new normal. This offers young Africans endless opportunities to serve in the virtual world of work and collaborate with business outside their geographical location.

    In conclusion

    Digital technologies have the potential to create more and better jobs for young Africans. It’s time for us to look at how we can build global in-demand skills and create added value to work in the digital economy.

    What are your thoughts on digital technologies and the future of work in Africa? Share with us in the comment section.");

nodes.html:
<button class="carousel-item__media-content-container" type="button" aria-haspopup="true" @click="openModal("article", null, "Pursuing a rewarding Career in the Digital economy- Workshop Overview!", "Dorothy Nakaggwa", "https://res.cloudinary.com/baobab-staging/image/upload/v1679593436/Pursuing-a-rewarding-career_-_Article_Media_Card_Header_qhdiqh_orkzmb_nmcnj3", "Pursuing a rewarding Career in the Digital economy- Workshop Overview!

    Last week I had a wonderful time hosting a live zoom workshop on “Pursuing a Rewarding Career in the Digital Economy.” It’s conversations like these that remind me of the power we have as young people to change the narrative of youth unemployment that has for so long ravaged the African Continent.

    As a freelance writer who has leveraged the internet to build a career online, it was a privilege to talk to other young people on how we can embrace digital technologies and position ourselves for the new opportunities created by the internet.

    In today’s blog, I’ll go over a few things that we talked about, and I hope you’ll learn about the potential of the internet to challenge unemployment in Africa.

    African Countries have had a tough time creating formal sector jobs for the youth for decades. As more youth enter the workforce, and thousands of graduates walk out of universities each year, many face the challenge of finding meaningful work on the continent.

    For graduates, this can be frustrating since most of us spend on average four years preparing to serve in different sectors of the economy. In the end, we are hit with the reality that these sectors can’t provide enough jobs for all of us.

    The Good News…

    Despite the grim employment outlook, there is a silver lining for young people ready to jump at the opportunities created by digital technologies. Whether you’re a tech-savvy or not, I believe we could all benefit from this revolution in different ways.

    A recent World Bank report on the future of work in Africa suggested that “If widely adopted, digital technologies hold the promise of helping firms grow, create more jobs for everyone, and most importantly increase the employment rate not only for university graduates, but for those workers who have a secondary, or even a primary level of education.”

    We can all agree that digital technologies are changing the nature of work and structure of employment, globally. The internet has created new markets, new roles, and new types of employment that initially didn’t exist.

    But how can young Africans embrace this revolution?

    First off, we talked about the forms of digital exclusion among young people in Africa. These included:

    Unware: These young people have experience with using the internet but don’t know where to find opportunities online.

    Unready: These have little or no internet experience and the key barriers are little or no internet access and minimal IT skills.

    Uninterested: This group has no internet experience and not interested in learning about opportunities online.

    Unable: This group has Poor literacy and English Language skills and can’t understand the value of the internet.

    Most of the workshop attendees were Unaware, and a few were Unready. This shows that we need to educate ourselves on the opportunities created by digital technologies and build our skill sets so we can position ourselves for this revolution.

    The “hidden” online job Market

    I call it “hidden” because no one in school ever mentioned to us the possibility of building a career online —  with just your laptop and an internet connection. The online job market offers individuals with in-demand skills an opportunity to build a rewarding career irrespective of your gender, nationality, and geographical location.

    During the workshop, we explored some in-demand skills and the new opportunities created by the internet. The skills included Virtual assistant, Accounting and bookkeeping, Google analytics, Digital Marketing, eCommerce, web design and development, etc. The jobs created by the internet included SEO specialist, Digital Marketer, online tutor, content marketer, User experience designer, etc.

    Workspaces Vs. Workplaces

    We couldn’t end the discussion without talking about the rise of remote working. As more businesses transition to new business models, remote working is becoming the new normal. This offers young Africans endless opportunities to serve in the virtual world of work and collaborate with business outside their geographical location.

    Digital technologies have the potential to create more and better jobs for young Africans. It’s time for us to look at how we can build global in-demand skills and create added value to work in the digital economy.

<button class="carousel-item__media-content-container" type="button" aria-haspopup="true" @click="openModal("article", null, "Pursuing a rewarding Career in the Digital economy- Workshop Overview!", "Dorothy Nakaggwa", "https://res.cloudinary.com/baobab-staging/image/upload/v1679593436/Pursuing-a-rewarding-career_-_Article_Media_Card_Header_qhdiqh_orkzmb_nmcnj3", "Pursuing a rewarding Career in the Digital economy- Workshop Overview!

    Last week I had a wonderful time hosting a live zoom workshop on “Pursuing a Rewarding Career in the Digital Economy.” It’s conversations like these that remind me of the power we have as young people to change the narrative of youth unemployment that has for so long ravaged the African Continent.

    As a freelance writer who has leveraged the internet to build a career online, it was a privilege to talk to other young people on how we can embrace digital technologies and position ourselves for the new opportunities created by the internet.

    In today’s blog, I’ll go over a few things that we talked about, and I hope you’ll learn about the potential of the internet to challenge unemployment in Africa.

    African Countries have had a tough time creating formal sector jobs for the youth for decades. As more youth enter the workforce, and thousands of graduates walk out of universities each year, many face the challenge of finding meaningful work on the continent.

    For graduates, this can be frustrating since most of us spend on average four years preparing to serve in different sectors of the economy. In the end, we are hit with the reality that these sectors can’t provide enough jobs for all of us.

    The Good News…

    Despite the grim employment outlook, there is a silver lining for young people ready to jump at the opportunities created by digital technologies. Whether you’re a tech-savvy or not, I believe we could all benefit from this revolution in different ways.

    A recent World Bank report on the future of work in Africa suggested that “If widely adopted, digital technologies hold the promise of helping firms grow, create more jobs for everyone, and most importantly increase the employment rate not only for university graduates, but for those workers who have a secondary, or even a primary level of education.”

    We can all agree that digital technologies are changing the nature of work and structure of employment, globally. The internet has created new markets, new roles, and new types of employment that initially didn’t exist.

    But how can young Africans embrace this revolution?

    First off, we talked about the forms of digital exclusion among young people in Africa. These included:

    Unware: These young people have experience with using the internet but don’t know where to find opportunities online.

    Unready: These have little or no internet experience and the key barriers are little or no internet access and minimal IT skills.

    Uninterested: This group has no internet experience and not interested in learning about opportunities online.

    Unable: This group has Poor literacy and English Language skills and can’t understand the value of the internet.

    Most of the workshop attendees were Unaware, and a few were Unready. This shows that we need to educate ourselves on the opportunities created by digital technologies and build our skill sets so we can position ourselves for this revolution.

    The “hidden” online job Market

    I call it “hidden” because no one in school ever mentioned to us the possibility of building a career online —  with just your laptop and an internet connection. The online job market offers individuals with in-demand skills an opportunity to build a rewarding career irrespective of your gender, nationality, and geographical location.

    During the workshop, we explored some in-demand skills and the new opportunities created by the internet. The skills included Virtual assistant, Accounting and bookkeeping, Google analytics, Digital Marketing, eCommerce, web design and development, etc. The jobs created by the internet included SEO specialist, Digital Marketer, online tutor, content marketer, User experience designer, etc.

    Workspaces Vs. Workplaces

    We couldn’t end the discussion without talking about the rise of remote working. As more businesses transition to new business models, remote working is becoming the new normal. This offers young Africans endless opportunities to serve in the virtual world of work and collaborate with business outside their geographical location.

    In conclusion

    Digital technologies have the potential to create more and better jobs for young Africans. It’s time for us to look at how we can build global in-demand skills and create added value to work in the digital economy.

    What are your thoughts on digital technologies and the future of work in Africa? Share with us in the comment section.");
